entry.title: 余额交易货币及结转余额详解
entry.content:
本文目的

  • 介绍余额交易货币（Balance Transaction Currency）在外币业务及跨币种清账业务下的逻辑
  • 介绍余额结转 (Balance Carry Forward) 过程中，余额交易货币的逻辑及相应报表查看

 

余额交易货币相关场景测试：

余额交易货币（Balance Transaction Currency）是SAP系统中用于管理和显示科目余额的重要货币类型。通常情况下，交易货币和余额交易货币是相同的，但在特定业务场景下（如发票为欧元而付款为美元），系统会使用欧元作为付款的余额交易货币，确保清账后余额交易货币金额为零。

勾选“仅以本币记的余额”时：

企业发生外币记账的业务，且对应总账科目勾选“仅以本币记的余额”

针对该总账科目使用交易货币USD进行过账：

以余额货币计的金额=以公司代码货币计的金额

 

未勾选“仅以本币记的余额”时：

企业发生外币记账的业务，且对应总账科目未勾选“仅以本币记的余额”

针对该总账科目使用交易货币USD进行过账：

以余额货币计的金额=以交易货币计的金额

 

未勾选“仅以本币记的余额”并进行跨币种清账业务：

企业存在跨币种清账业务，如原应收/应付发票的交易货币为USD，使用CNY直接针对发票进行清账

企业存在交易货币为外币的应收账款/应付账款

针对该交易货币为USD发票，使用CNY进行付款并清账：

针对应收/应付账款行项目，以余额货币计的金额=原发票的外币金额

系统以原始交易货币作为余额交易货币，确保在该货币基础上进行清账平衡计算。当外币发票发票与本币付款之间因汇率变动产生差异时，余额交易货币确保系统能够正确处理汇率差异，自动计算并过账汇兑损益。在余额交易货币下，系统确保清账后的净余额为零，即使使用不同货币进行清账。

 

结转余额相关场景测试：

勾选“仅以本币记的余额”的资产负债表科目：

期末余额（年末结转余额前）：

期初余额（结转余额后）：

因结转余额考虑“余额货币”，如勾选“仅以本币记的余额”后，余额借转后的期初余额仅以本币显示，“交易货币”下的金额在余额结转后，也仅显示为公司代码货币金额。

 

未勾选“仅以本币记的余额”的资产负债表科目：

期末余额（年末结转余额前）：

期初余额（结转余额后）：

因结转余额考虑“余额货币”，如勾选“仅以本币记的余额”后，余额借转后的“交易货币”下的金额以公司代码货币显示。“余额货币“列的金额会按照期末余额结转至期初。

 

结论：

  • 余额交易货币（Balance Transaction Currency）是中用于管理和显示科目余额的重要货币类型，与总账科目主数据中“仅以本币记的余额”有关。未勾选“仅以本币记的余额”时，交易货币和余额交易货币是相同的，但在特定业务场景下（如发票为USD而付款为CNY），系统会使用USD作为付款的余额交易货币，确保清账后余额交易货币金额为零。
  • 在余额结转 (Balance Carry Forward) 过程中，系统使用余额交易货币（Balance Transaction Currency）作为主要的货币基准来确保多货币环境下余额的准确传递。
  • 在余额结转后，如需要查看资产负债表科目的期初外币余额，需要使用App: 试算平衡表，，并选择“以余额货币计的期初余额”进行查看，详情参考：2765202 - Trial balance does not show opening balance in transaction currency - SAP for Me
  • 如企业存在跨币种清账的业务（如发票为USD而付款为CNY），在App: 显示客户往来科目汇总表 - 中国/显示供应商往来科目汇总表 - 中国，发现年初余额和以前年度期末余额显示不一致，建议使用App: 试算平衡表，，并选择“以余额货币计的期初余额”进行查看，详情参考：3631436 - Discrepancy Between Year-beginning Balance and Year-Ending Balances in Transactional Currency (Display Customer/Supplier Summary- China Apps) - SAP for Me

entry.title: Cutting Through the Complexity: Lease Accounting in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Lease accounting under IFRS 16 and ASC 842 continues to challenge finance and project teams alike. The calculations themselves are straightforward — it’s the classification and operational handling that create complexity.

In SAP Cloud ERP, the Contract and Lease Management (CLM) functionality simplifies this challenge by delivering a standardized, automated approach for both lessee and lessor accounting.

This blog explains how the system supports different lease types — and what that means in practical terms for finance teams adopting a clean-core cloud solution.

Lessee Accounting – For Companies Using Assets

If your business leases assets such as office space, vehicles, or equipment, you’re acting as a lessee. The system handles these scenarios through Scope Item 1T6: Lease-In Accounting.

When you activate a lease contract, S/4HANA Cloud automatically:

  • Calculates the Right-of-Use (ROU) asset and lease liability based on future payments.
  • Posts interest expense on the liability and depreciation on the asset each period.
  • Integrates everything into the Universal Journal for full auditability.

From a finance perspective, this means that once the contract data is entered correctly, the system takes care of recognition and periodic postings — freeing you from manual calculations or offline models.

IFRS 16 vs ASC 842: Two Frameworks, One Process

  • IFRS 16 treats nearly all leases as finance leases — meaning they appear on the balance sheet.
  • ASC 842, used in the US, distinguishes between:
    • Finance leases, where interest and depreciation are shown separately.
    • Operating leases, where the expense appears as a single straight-line amount in the income statement, even though both the asset and liability exist in the background.

Both standards are supported natively. This allows multinational organizations to run a single process while reporting correctly under different frameworks.

Short-Term and Low-Value Exemptions

S/4HANA Cloud also supports the practical exemptions under IFRS 16 — for leases under 12 months or of low-value assets. These are recorded but not capitalized, keeping disclosure complete without overstating the balance sheet.

Explore more: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Contract & Lease Management – Simplify and Lower the Cost of Compliance

Lessor Accounting – For Companies Providing Assets

Some organizations lease out their own equipment, vehicles, or real estate. In these cases, you’re the lessor.

The Public Edition supports standard lessor models under both IFRS 16 and ASC 842, helping finance teams recognize income correctly depending on the nature of the lease.

Finance Lease (IFRS 16)

If the lessee effectively takes on most of the risks and rewards of ownership:

  • The asset is replaced by a lease receivable.
  • Income is recognized as interest over the lease term.

Sales-Type Lease (ASC 842)

Used when the lease is effectively a sale at commencement:

  • Revenue and cost of goods sold are recognized immediately.
  • Interest income is then recognized over time.

Direct Financing Lease (ASC 842)

Applied when there is no upfront selling profit:

  • A lease receivable is created.
  • Income arises gradually through interest over the lease period.

In practice, most organizations using CLM in the Public Edition are handling a limited number of such lessor contracts — for example, internal leasing of IT assets or vehicles between entities — rather than running a large-scale commercial leasing operation.

Learn more: Enabling a Renting Business Model with SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Subscription Billing

Making the Right Call on Lease Type

The most common challenge project teams face is not the posting itself — it’s the classification decision at the start.
The following simple logic can help you decide which path applies:

  1. Are you the user or provider of the asset?
    → User → Lessee Accounting (Scope Item 1T6)
    → Provider → Lessor Accounting
  2. Which reporting standard applies?
    • If yes → Finance or Sales-Type Lease.
    • If no → Operating or Direct Financing Lease.
    • IFRS 16 → All leases (except short-term/low-value) are Finance Leases.
    • ASC 842 → Determine whether the lease transfers ownership or risk.
  3. Enter the contract in CLM using the relevant Fiori app — the system will handle valuation and posting automatically.

Key Takeaways

  • Lessee accounting (Scope Item 1T6) is the core capability in Cloud ERP.
  • The system supports both IFRS 16 and ASC 842 with standard content.
  • Lessor models (Finance, Sales-Type, Direct Financing) are available for entities providing assets.
  • The clean-core approach minimizes maintenance and simplifies audit readiness.

Learn More

  • SAP Help Portal – Contract and Lease Management (Public Edition)
  • SAP Community Topic: Finance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Learning Hub – Lease Accounting Fundamentals
  • SAP Best Practices Explorer – Scope Item 1T6

entry.title: Argentina Withholding Tax: Understanding the General Resolutions 5762/2025 and 5764/2025
entry.content:
Business Context

The Argentinian tax authority, ARCA, published General Resolution 5762/2025 and General Resolution 5764/2025.

These resolutions, known locally as Resoluciones Generales (RG), repeal the previous RG 1575/2003 and replace the "M" letter documents with "A" letter documents, which now feature specific descriptions:

  • “OPERACIÓN SUJETA A RETENCIÓN” (Transaction Subject to Withholding Tax)
  • “PAGO EN CBU INFORMADA” (Payment with Unique Bank Key)

Extra information: The “M” billing requirement targeted newly operating companies, those with incomplete tax compliance, or insufficient patrimonial solvency.

Who is it Relevant For?

The changes primarily impact VAT-registered taxpayers ("Responsables Inscriptos en IVA"). ARCA will evaluate these companies every four months to determine if they can be treated as normal taxpayers, potentially removing the descriptions from their documents.

Document Codes

Following these changes, the document codes are now organized depending on the descriptions featured:

1. Operación Sujeta a Retención (Transaction Subject to Withholding Tax)

051: Invoice “A”

052: Debit Note “A”

053: Credit Note “A”

2. Pago en CBU Informada (Payment with Unique Bank Key)

001: Invoice “A”

002: Debit Note “A”

003: Credit Note “A”

Final Considerations

Regarding withholding taxes, payments to letter “A” documents with the description “Operación Sujeta a Retención” must be calculated as follows:

  • VAT: 100% over the VAT of the paid invoice, SIRE code 499
  • Earning tax: 6% over the payment (net of taxes), SICORE code 99

Businesses using SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA can customize their systems to comply with these new requirements. For practical guidance on how to meet this legal requirement in your SAP system, refer to SAP Note 3696508.

These changes aim to streamline tax compliance and ensure transparency in business transactions. As businesses adapt, staying informed and prepared will be key to a smooth transition.

For more details on this legal change, check the regulatory change manager tool under Changes: New Class A Invoice Categories and Withholding Regime.

Thank you for taking the time to read and until next time,

Juliana Ghisleni

entry.title: Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog introduces the major position change-relevant posting journals, position flows (include derived business transactions) and position components’ value change logic, over the full life of an interest-rate instrument, using an illustrative example created in the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Illustrative Example

Data Preparation

Prepare the exchange rates between USD/EUR and EUR/USD.

Create an interest rate instrument (transaction type 100 - investment) and settle it.

“Structure” of this transaction:

This transaction uses transaction currency USD. The nominal amount is 1,000,000.00 USD, the payment amount (for the initial principal increase flow) is 998,000.00 USD, so there is discount 2,000.00 USD. This transaction uses installment repayment for repayment structure.

An outgoing payment flow for charge (capitalized) is added in “Other Flows”. This flow is settled in EUR (≠ transaction currency USD).

Check position indicator. The position currency (PC) is USD (=transaction currency), and the valuation currency (VC) is EUR (=local currency of the company code).

The example will focus on valuation area 002 (IFRS). 002 uses a position management procedure (PMP) 1IAS for this transaction, this PMP is designed for the measurement of the investment in debt instrument which is classified as “Fair Value through Other Comprehensive Income (FVOCI)” (in terminology of IFRS 9). This PMP contains three valuation steps: amortization, security (M2M) valuation, FX valuation. You may ask why choosing FVOCI in this example, it is because FVOCI is more complicated than other classifications, such as amortized cost (no security valuation) or FVTPL (no amortization), and its security valuation doesn’t affect P/L (instead it affects OCI).

Check “Cash Flow”:

Initial Recognition and Measurement

Run Fix, Pay and Post Flows (app ID: TBB1) on 24.10.2025.

Posting log:

  • MM1100-: principal increase amount in PC is 998,000.00 USD, its amount in VC = 998,000.00* 0.8543 = 852,591.40 EUR. 0.8543 is the exchange rate on 24.10.2025.
  • MM1902-: the payment currency amount of flow 1902 is 100.00 EUR, its credit side is posted in bank clearing account with the transaction currency (TC, =PC) EUR, but its debit side recognizes position which must be posted in position currency USD, and its amount = 100.00 EUR / 0.8543=117.05 USD, therefore, the clearing account is involved in the journal entries of MM1902- and it has the identical amounts in VC within two journal entries.

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check the position values in app Treasury Position Values -Classic (app ID: TPM12).

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

In the calculation schema above, purchase value, amortization, security valuation, and FX valuation are the original position components; acquisition value, amortized acquisition value, and book value are the derived position components, which are based on original position components and are determined by adding or subtracting original position components. This is a simplified schema that includes only the position components used in the illustrative example. For a complete understanding for original components and derived counterparts, please check the help document Position Components.

In this example, at initial recognition, only the position component purchase value is updated, and it is equal to the book value of this transaction. The purchase value is sourced from position flows with update types MM1100- and MM1902- on 24.10.2025. To verify which position component has been updated, you may check the Position Change Category in the app Treasury Position Flows - Classic (app ID: TPM13).

(You may see the Position Change Category of MM1902- is “Post Cost to Purchase Value Component”, that’s the reason why the position change arising from the transaction cost MM1902- is also included in position component purchase value. This effect is specified in configuration activity 102097 “Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components”. In this configuration, you may assign another position change category “1014-Post Costs to Costs Component” to MM1902-, then MM1902- will be included in a standalone position component called “capitalized costs”, but this example will not elaborate it.)

In addition, on 24.10.2025, the unamortized discount = nominal 1,000,000.00 - Amortized Acquisition Value 998,117.05 = 1,882.95 USD. It can also be expressed in the following manner: (1,000,000.00 - 998,000.00) - 117.05 = 1,882.95 USD.

In this example, the unamortized discount is neither reflected in a standalone position component and nor reflected in a separate G/L account. This example’s amortization procedure uses the so-called “net method”; if the “gross method” is used in amortization procedure, then the unamortized discount can be managed in the position component for “premium/discount” and posted in a separate discount account, the position account will reflect the nominal 1,000,000.00 USD.

Subsequent Measurement

Month end closing (31.10.2025)

This transaction is classified as FVOCI, enter the NPV (fair value) 999,000.00 USD for 31.10.2025.

Execute valuation via app Run Valuation (app ID: TPM1).

The valuation log contains three steps:

The amortization log can be checked from TPM1:

The details for amortization log are not elaborated here. One thing is worth noting is that here the amortization procedure uses the effective interest rate (EIR) method, EIR was calculated when initial recognition.

Posting log for TPM1:

  • V300: the amount in PC is 286.34 USD, the details can be found from the amortization log. Its amount in VC = 286.34*0.8543 = 244.62 EUR, the exchange rate 0.8543 is the old exchange rate (on 24.10.2025) which was applied to the previous position change when initial recognition. With the position change effect of V300, the amortized acquisition value (AAV) in PC = 998,117.05 + 286.34 = 998,403.39, the AAV in VC = 852,691.40 +  244.62 = 852,936.02 EUR.
  • V200_OCI: the amount in PC = 999,000.00 - 998,403.39 = 596.61USD, the amount in VC = 596.61 * 0.8543 = 509.68 EUR, here the old exchange rate (on 24.10.2025) is applied. With the position change effect of V300, the position value in PC = 998,403.39 + 596.61 = 999,000.00 USD (= the fair value in USD), and the position value in VC = 852,936.02 + 509.68 = 853,445.70 EUR.
  • V203: 999,000.00*0.8512=850,348.80 EUR, this is the book value applied with the latest exchange rate on 31.10.2025; 850,348.80 - 853,445.70 = -3,096.90 EUR, 3,096.90 EUR is the unrealized FX valuation loss recognized during valuation run.

The update types used for valuation are specified in configuration activity 104116 “Assign Update Types for Valuation”.

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check TPM13:

Check TPM12:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

The unamortized discount = 1,000,000.00 - 998,403.39 = 1,882.95 - 286.34 =1,596.61 USD.

Installment repayment (Partial Derecognition, 24.11.2025)

Run TBB1 on 24.11.2025, the first installment repayment (500,000.00 USD) occurs at this date. From accounting perspective, the investment position is partially derecognized.

Positing log:

These 4 position flows with DBT_E* update types are not relevant to posting, they are only fixed:

Let us now look at the following two position flows:

  • MM1130+: this position flow (500,000.00 USD in PC) is an operational business transaction which receives the installment repayment from counterparty and recognizes the principal decrease because of installment repayment; its amount in VC = 500,000.00* 0.8548 = 427,400.00 EUR; 0.8548 is the latest exchange rate for 24.11.2025.
  • DBT_C002: this is the derived business transaction for amortization (with “net method”), it is created automatically along with the original business transaction (MM1130+). For the details regarding how it is calculated, you may access TPM13, select the position flow DBT_C002, and click the button “Amort. Simulation” to check the detailed amortization log. Here, its amount in PC is 982.34 USD, its amount in VC = 982.34*0.8512=836.17 EUR; 0.8512 is the old exchange rate on 31.10.2025.

Check TPM13:

Amortization log (for DBT_C002):

Let’s now recap—before considering the effect of repayment flow—which position components make up the transaction’s book value, including the impact of DBT_C002.

Book value = purchase value + amortization + security valuation + FX valuation = 999,982.34 USD (851,184.97 EUR).

Upon repayment, the proportion of the nominal amount repaid to the original nominal determines how much of the position should be derecognized along with repayment. In this example, nominal decrease because of repayment 500,000.00 USD / total original nominal 1,000,000.00 USD = 50%; therefore, 50% of the book value (position) should be derecognized, the to be derecognized book value = 499,991.17 USD (425,592.49 EUR).

Now, let’s have a look at how and why the following four derived business transactions are calculated (they are not relevant to posting, no posting journals are generated directly from them).

  • DBT_E001: till now, the amount in PC of position component purchase value is 998,117.05 USD; 998,117.05*50%=499,058.53 USD. The amount in VC of position component purchase value is 852,691.40 EUR; 852,691.40*50%=426,345.70 EUR. The position flow of DBT_E001 carries the amounts of proportionate purchase value which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E003: till now, the amount in PC of position component securities valuation is 596.61 USD; 596.61*50%=298.30 USD. The amount in VC of position component securities valuation is 509.68 EUR; 509.68*50%=254.84 EUR. The position flow of DBT_E003 carries the amounts of proportionate securities valuation which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E006: till now, the amount in VC of position component FX valuation is -3,096.90 EUR; -3,096.90 *50%=-1,548.45EUR. DBT_E006 carries the amounts of proportionate FX valuation which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E017: till now, the amount in PC of position component amortization is 1,268.68 USD; 1,268.68*50%=634.34 USD. The amount in VC of position component amortization is 1,080.79 EUR; 1,080.79*50%=540.40 EUR. DBT_E017 carries the amounts of proportionate amortization which should be derecognized upon repayment.

Verify the book values to be derecognized again by summing the amounts of these position flows of DBT_E*:

  • The book value in PC to be derecognized = 499,058.53+298.30+634.34=499,991.17 USD.
  • The book value in VC to be derecognized = 426,345.70+254.84-1548.45+540.40=425,592.49 EUR.

Viewed differently, the DBT_E* position flows break down the book value that will be derecognized into its individual position component pieces.

MM1130+ derecognizes the investment position 500,000.00 USD (PC) and 427,400.00 EUR (VC), they are the real incoming payment amounts because of repayment. However, there are differences between MM1130+ and above calculated book values in PC and VC to be derecognized, therefore, derived business transactions DBT_B002 and DBT_B006 are generated to handle the differences:

  • DBT_B002: 500,000.00-499,991.17=8.83 USD; 8.83*0.8512=7.52 EUR, here the old exchange rate 0.8512 is applied. DBT_B002 is the realized price gain because derecognized book value in PC is less than the received repayment amount in PC.
  • DBT_B006: 427,400.00-425,592.49-7.52=1799.99 EUR. DBT_B006 is the realized FX gain because the derecognized book value in VC is less than the received repayment amount in VC.

The combination of MM1300+, DBT_B002, and DBT_B006 causes exactly 499,991.17 USD and 425,592.49 EUR are subtracted from the position account upon repayment, meanwhile DBT_B002 and DBT_B006 also recognize the realized gain/loss arising from repayment directly, from accounting perspective. Till now, the position account-relevant journals and balance in T-accounts are as follows:

Check TPM12:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

Previously we have explained DBT_E003, it carries the security valuation component to be derecognized: 298.30 USD (PC) and 254.84 EUR (VC). Consequently, the proportionate fair value change that was earlier recognized in OCI shall be reclassified to P&L because of partial derecognition of position; from an accounting perspective, DBS_E025 performs this reclassification adjustment posting, it carries the same amounts (in PC and VC) as DBT_E003.

Till now, the unamortized discount = 500,000.00 - 499,692.86 = 307.14 USD. You will see this unamortized discount will be amortized via the position flow of DBT_C002 on 24.12.2025 in the next section.

From a configuration perspective, which update types are invoked for relevant derived business transactions is specified in Configuration Activity 104116 “Assign Update Types for Derived Business Transactions”.

Derecognition

Final Repayment (last installment repayment, 24.12.2025)

Run TBB1 on 24.12.2025. Posting log:

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check TPM13:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

No detailed walk-through of the complete derecognition-related position flows and postings is provided here, as the mechanics mirror those already described for subsequent measurement. In short, complete derecognition reduces the position value to zero.

Other Configuration

In this illustrative example, the position flows for Derived Business Transactions (update type DBT_*) are already generated and fixed and posted (if posting relevant) when the original business transaction leads to position change, this is because that in the configuration activity 104456 “Control Processing of Derived Business Transactions”, the field “On/Offline” is specified as “Online”, and “Status Control” is specified as “Same Status”.

Field “Online/Offline”:

  • Online: if you select “online”, then the derived business transactions are updated immediately every time an original business transaction leads to a change in a position. This setting is the predefined setting in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Offline: if you select “Offline”, then the derived business transactions are not generated immediately. To generate derived business transactions, you can sue the app Update Derived Business Transactions (app ID: TPM27).

Field “Status Control”:

  • Same Status: the Derived business transactions always have the same status as the original business transaction.
  • Status Plan: the Derived business transactions are always generated with Plan (scheduled) status. You can use the app Post Derived Business Transactions (app ID: TPM18) to fix and post derived business transactions. Note: Some functions (such as the key date valuation) require that derived business transactions no longer have the status Plan.

Help Document

Please check help document Position Components for more details regarding position components.

Please check help document Derived Business Transactions for more details regarding derived business transactions.

entry.title: Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog mainly introduces how accrual (app ID: TPM44) works and what are the differences between reset procedure and difference procedure in Treasury and Risk Management (TRM), using illustrative examples based on the predefined configuration within S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Due to space constraints, this blog covers only the accrual and omits any discussion of deferral. You can always check help document Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues for more details regarding accrual and deferral.

Reset Procedure

First, let’s have a look at the following screen-shot taken from the configuration activity 102925 “Assign Update Types for Accrual/Deferral”.

Explanation for this configuration:

  • Profit-related flow MM1200+ is the update type for the nominal interest for an investment transaction of money market instrument. Its posting specification debits bank clearing (if payment request is not used) and credits interest income.
  • Reset Procedure is applied to the accrual of interest income on the source flow MM1200+.
  • The accrual of interest income is achieved via update type AD1000, and resetting accrual is done via AD1001.

The example below illustrates the reset procedure-based accrual of interest income for an investment transaction of interest rate instrument. This transaction starts on 01.10.2025, matures on 01.04.2026, interest rate is 3% (act/360), interest frequency is 2 months, start date of the interest period is included in the interest calculation. This transaction’s transaction/payment currency is USD, so its position currency is USD, whereas the valuation currency is EUR (=local currency of company code).

Check cash flow as below. The principal increase flow (flow type 1100, on 01.10.2025) has been fixed and posted. The next interest payment is on 01.12.2025.

At the October 2025 month-end close, the portion of interest income attributable to October should be accrued under accrual accounting.

Open the app Run Accrual/Deferral (app ID TPM44), and enter following data on its initial screen, the key date is 31.10.2025.

Execute TPM44, and check the log. System picks up the MM1200+ interest flow with calculation from 01.10.2025 to 01.12.2025, totally 61 days in this interest period, its amount in position currency is 5,083.33 USD. There are 31 days from 01.10.2025 to 31.10.2025 (because key date is included), therefore, the accrual amount in position currency =31/61*5,083.33=2,583.33 USD. The accrual amount in valuation currency=2,583.33*0.8512=2,198.93 EUR; 0.8512 is the exchange rate as of 31.10.2025. The accrual is recognized via AD1000, and it is reset via AD1001.

Check the posting log:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 31.10.2025 and the interest income recognized via accrual in October, after the accrual has been posted:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 01.11.2025 and the cumulative interest income recognized through that date, after the accrual has been reset:

At the next month-end close of November, execute TPM44 for key date 30.11.2025. Check the log. System still picks up the MM1200+ interest flow with calculation from 01.10.2025 to 01.12.2025, totally 61 days in this interest period, its amount in position currency is 5,083.33 USD. There are 61 days from 01.10.2025 to 30.11.2025 (because key date is included), therefore, the accrual amount in position currency =61/61*5,083.33=5,083.33 USD. The accrual amount in valuation currency = 5,083.33*0.8548=4,345.23 EUR; 0.8548 is the exchange rate as of 30.11.2025. The accrual is recognized via AD1000, and it is reset via AD1001.

Check the posting log:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 30.11.2025, and the interest income recognized via accrual in November (5,083.33-2,583.33=2,500.00 USD in position currency; 4,345.23-2,198.93=2,146.30 EUR in valuation currency), and the cumulative interest income recognized through 30.11.2025 (5,083.33 USD in position currency; 4,345.23 EUR in valuation currency), after the accrual has been posted:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 01.12.2025 and the cumulative interest income recognized through that date, after the accrual has been reset:

Access app Fix, Pay and Post Flows (app ID TBB1) to fix and post the MM1200+ interest flow on 01.12.2025. Check the posting log, MM1200+ debits bank clearing and credits interest income, the amount in position currency is 5,083.33 USD, the amount in valuation currency = 5,083.33*0.8475=4,308.12 EUR; 0.8475 is the exchange rate as of 01.12.2025.

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 01.12.2025 and the cumulative interest income recognized through that date, after the MM1200+ has been posted:

The cumulative interest income is fully recognized by MM1200+, because accruals are all reset.

At the next month-end close of December, execute TPM44 for key date 31.12.2025. Check the log:

System involves the MM1200+ interest flow with calculation from 01.12.2025 to 01.02.2026 into the accrual calculation for December. The logic is the same as described above and will not be repeated here.

It is worth noting that the fixed MM1200+ flow on 01.12. 2025 is excluded from the accrual calculation at 31.12.2025, because its interest income has been recognized via the posting of MM1200+ directly. This is one of the differences between the reset procedure and the difference procedure. The latter includes the fixed interest flow in the accrual calculation, and more details are provided in the next section.

Let’s now move on to the next section, "Difference Procedure".

Difference Procedure

First, let’s change the configuration as below in the configuration activity 102925 “Assign Update Types for Accrual/Deferral”.

Explanation for this configuration:

  • Profit-related flow MM1200+ is the update type for the nominal interest for an investment transaction of money market instrument. Its posting specification debits bank clearing (if payment request is not used) and credits accrual account, this is different from MM1200+’s posting spec under reset procedure.
  • Difference Procedure is applied to the accrual of interest income on the source flow MM1200+.
  • The accrual of interest income is achieved via update type AD1004; FX corrections are posted via AD1020 (positive) or AD1021 (negative).

The structure of the transaction used for illustrating difference procedure is the same as the transaction used for the reset procedure above.

Check cash flow. The principal increase flow (flow type 1100, on 01.10.2025) has been fixed and posted. The next interest payment is on 01.12.2025.

 At the October 2025 month-end close, the portion of interest income attributable to October should be accrued under accrual accounting.

Execute TPM44 for key date 31.10.2025, and check the log. System picks up the MM1200+ interest flow with calculation from 01.10.2025 to 01.12.2025, totally 61 days in this interest period, its amount in position currency is 5,083.33 USD. There are 31 days from 01.10.2025 to 31.10.2025 (because key date is included), therefore, the accrual amount in position currency =31/61*5,083.33=2,583.33 USD. The accrual amount in valuation currency = 2,583.33*0.8512=2198.93 EUR; 0.8512 is the latest exchange rate for 31.10.2025. The accrual is recognized via AD1004, and there is no reset of accrual.

Check the posting log:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 31.10.2025 and the interest income recognized via accrual in October, after the accrual has been posted:

At the next month-end close of November, execute TPM44 for key date 30.11.2025. Check the log:

System does the following calculations:

  • System picks up the MM1200+ interest flow with calculation from 01.10.2025 to 01.12.2025, totally 61 days in this interest period, its amount in position currency is 5,083.33 USD. There are 61 days from 01.10.2025 to 30.11.2025 (because key date is included), therefore, the cumulative accrual amount in position currency =61/61*5,083.33=5,083.33 USD, and the cumulative accrual amount in valuation currency =5,083.33*0.8548=4,345.23 EUR, 0.8548 is the exchange rate as of 30.11.2025.
  • Because the accrued income in October is 2,583.33 USD in position currency, the incremental accrual amount in position currency in November=5,083.33-2,583.33=2,500.00 USD; 2,500.00*0.8548=2,137.00 EUR. Therefore, the amounts of AD1004 as of 30.11.2025 are 2,500.00 USD in position currency and 2,137.00 EUR in valuation currency.
  • Because the accrued income in October is 2,198.93 EUR in valuation currency, the incremental accrual amount in valuation currency in November=4,345.23-2,198.93=2,146.30 EUR.
  • AD1004 as of 30.11.2025 carries 2,137.00 EUR in valuation currency, the difference, 2,146.30-2,137.00=9.30 EUR, is treated as the FX correction (positive) which is to be recognized via AD1020. You may also regard the FX correction as the ‘FX valuation’ for the accrual up to 31.10.30 (2,583.33 USD) specifically, the amount of this ‘FX valuation’ = 2,583.33 * (0.8548 - 0.8512) = 9.30 EUR. AD1020 only posts in valuation currency (the amount in position currency is 0).

Check the posting log:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 30.11.2025, and the interest income recognized via accruals in October and November and their cumulative effect:

(Here AD1020 credits interest income, you may choose to credit it on FX gain account via modifying the account determination configuration based on your requirement)

Open app Treasury Position Flows - Classic (app ID TPM13), in which you can select position flow AD1004 as of 30.11.2025, click the button “Orig.Bus.Trans”, system will show you the detailed figures about accrual (which have been explained above).

Access app Fix, Pay and Post Flows (app ID TBB1) to fix and post the MM1200+ interest flow on 01.12.2025. Check the posting log, MM1200+ debits bank clearing and credits accrual account (this is different from the posting spec of MM1200+ under reset method, for which you may also need to change MM1200+’s account determination configuration), the amount in position currency is 5,083.33 USD, the amount in valuation currency = 5,083.33*0.8475=4,308.12 EUR; 0.8475 is the exchange rate as of 01.12.2025.

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 01.12.2025 and the cumulative interest income recognized through that date, after the MM1200+ has been posted. Accrual account has the balance 37.11 EUR in valuation currency, which looks “abnormal”, the TPM44 run at the end of December will “correct” it.

At the next month-end close of December, execute TPM44 for key date 31.12.2025. Check the log:

System does the following calculations:

  • System picks up two MM1200+ interest flows:
    • One MM1200+ has been fixed on 01.12.2025, its amounts 5,083.33 USD (in position currency) and 4,308.12 EUR (in valuation currency) are directly taken from the fixed position flow, they are also the amounts already recognized in accrual account via the posting of MM1200+ done by TBB1.
    • Another MM1200+ is still unfixed/planned. Its calculation from data is 01.12.2025 and calculation to date is 01.02.2026, totally 62 days in this interest period, its amount in position currency is 5,166.67 USD. There are 31 days from 01.12.2025 to 31.12.2025 (because key date is included), therefore, the accrual amount in position currency arising from this interest flow =31/62*5,166.67=2,583.33 USD, and the accrual amount in valuation currency =2,583.33*0.8498=2,195.31 EUR, 0.8548 is the exchange rate as of 30.11.2025.
  • The aggregate accrual in position currency from these two interest flows=5,083.33+2,583.33=7,666.66 USD.
  • The aggregate accrual in valuation currency from these two interest flows=4,308.12+2,195.31=6,503.43 EUR.
  • The aggregate accrual occurred in position currency in October and November (recorded in these two months’ AD1004)=2,583.33+2,500.00=5,083.33 USD.
  • The aggregate accrual occurred in valuation currency in October and November (recorded in these two months’ AD1004 and AD1020)=2,198.93+2,137.00+9.30=4,345.23 EUR.
  • The incremental accrual amount in position currency in December=7,666.66-5,083.33 =2,583.33 USD; 2,583.33*0.8498=2,195.31 EUR. Therefore, the amounts of AD1004 as of 31.12.2025 are 2,583.33 USD in position currency and 2,195.31 EUR in valuation currency.
  • The incremental accrual amount in valuation currency in December=6,503.43-4,345.23 =2,158.20 EUR.
  • AD1004 as of 31.12.2025 carries 2,195.31 EUR in valuation currency, the difference, 2,158.20-2,195.31=-37.11 EUR, is treated as the FX correction (negative) which is to be recognized via AD1021. You may also calculate this FX correction in this way: 5,083.33 USD * (0.8475 - 0.8548) = -37.11 EUR, as it ‘fills’ the gap of exchange rate between the MM1200+ flow is fixed on 01.12.2025 (0.8475) and the MM1200+ flow is accrued on 30.11.2025 (0.8548). AD1021 only posts in valuation currency (the amount in position currency is 0).

Check the posting log:

Use T-accounts to illustrate the balance of the accrual account as of 30.11.2025, and the interest income recognized via accruals in 3 months and their cumulative effect.

You may notice that, after TPM44 run on 31.12.2025, the accrual account only reflects the amounts related to the unfixed MM1200+ flow (2,583.33 USD / 2,195.31 EUR). This does not mean the fixed MM1200+ flow has been ignored or excluded from accrual calculation; it simply means the fixed flow’s accrual base is exactly equal to the amount already posted for MM1200+ flow via TBB1 on 01.12.2025. Because the two figures are identical, they offset each other in the accrual account, leaving only the incremental piece of the unfixed interest flow on the books.

You can also see that the cumulative interest income is 7,666.66 USD and 6,503.43 EUR, although they are all recognized through execution of TPM44 (no recognition of interest income is from MM1200+ interest flow), they can be explained in the following way:

  • 7,666.66 USD = 5,083.33 USD from the fixed interest flow + accrual amount 2,583.33 USD from the unfixed interest flow.
  • 6,503.43 EUR = 4,308.12 EUR from the fixed interest flow (applied with the exchange rate as of posting date of this interest flow) + accrual amount 2,195.31 EUR from the unfixed interest flow (applied with exchange rate as of the key date of TPM44 run).

In a word, the difference procedure treats TPM44 as the sole engine for recognition of interest income from the nominal interest flows: it incrementally processes every relevant interest flow—fixed and unfixed—and books the delta directly to the accrual account. When the flow is fixed and posted via TBB1 (or TPM10), its credit to the accrual account perfectly offsets the accrual recognized through TPM44, leaving the accrual account with a balance that reflects only the proportional accrual from as-yet-unfixed interest flows after TPM44 run.

Open app Treasury Position Flows - Classic (app ID TPM13), in which you can select position flow AD1004 as of 31.12.2025, click the button “Orig.Bus.Trans”, system will show you the detailed figures about accrual (which have been explained above).

Additional note on the difference procedure: if no update type is assigned to “FX Corr. Positive” or “FX Corr. Negative” in the configuration as shown below, TPM44 still performs the FX correction and defaults to AD1004 for “FX Corr. Positive” and AD1001 for “FX Corr. Negative”.

Additional Notes

  • Exchange rates used in the examples:

  • App Reverse Accrual/Deferral (app ID: TPM45) is used to reverse accrual or deferral done by TPM44.
  • For the accrual that should be considered during Legacy Data Transfer, please refer to another blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions.
  • For the financial transactions adopting risk-free rates (e.g. SOFR, €STR), the variable interest flows should use the interest calculation types Compound Interest Calculation and Average Compound Interest Calculation, please configure the Grouping Term in configuration activity 102925 “Assign Update Types for Accrual/Deferral” for accrual/deferral of interest income or expenses for such kind of transactions. Please refer to blog Manage Risk-free Rate (RFR) Interest Rate Instrument with Accumulating Condition for a detailed example.

entry.title: SAP CPQ - Headless Configurator (Configurations v2 API)
entry.content:
What is the Headless Configurator?

The Headless Configurator decouples the user interface from the configuration engine. Instead of relying on SAP CPQ’s native UI, external applications—such as eCommerce sites, dealer portals, mobile apps, or kiosks—can call SAP CPQ’s Configuration V2 API to handle all configuration logic, rules, and pricing in real time.

This means:

  • Your front-end remains lightweight and fully customizable.
  • SAP CPQ continues to be the single source of truth for product rules and pricing.
  • No duplication of logic across channels.

How It Works

  1. Create Configuration
    External systems initiate a configuration session by calling the Create Configuration endpoint with product and context parameters (Market, Pricebook, Currency, Effective Date, Business Partners).

  2. Dynamic Updates
    Every attribute change triggers a Patch Configuration call. SAP CPQ responds with updated valid values, rule messages, and pricing deltas—ensuring guided selling and compliance.

  3. Finalize and Order
    Once configuration is complete, the external system retrieves the final configuration and either:

    • Places the order directly in ERP, S/4 HANA or S/4 HANA Public Cloud or
    • Creates a quote in SAP CPQ for sales-assisted workflows.

Primary Use Cases

  1. 3rd‑party eCommerce: A modern online shopping interface with a dynamic product configurator and real-time pricing updates in the cart.
  2. Reseller/Dealer Portal: A professional dashboard with tailored product variants and pricebook context, emphasizing collaboration and customization.
  3. Self‑Service Web/Mobile: An enterprise buyer using a tablet to configure complex assets independently, with an option to escalate to sales.
  4. Embedded Apps: A field technician at a kiosk using a lightweight app with SAP CPQ rules and pricing integrated seamlessly.
    The scene should feature a clean, high-tech aesthetic with glowing UI elements, holographic screens, and a connected network theme. Use vibrant colors like blue, teal, and white to convey trust, innovation, and transparency. Include subtle SAP branding elements without overpowering the design. Style: ultra-realistic with a touch of futuristic minimalism.

Why It Matters

The Configuration V2 API is more than a technical upgrade—it’s a strategic enabler for omnichannel selling, digital transformation, and partner ecosystem growth. By centralizing configuration intelligence in SAP CPQ and exposing it headlessly, businesses can innovate faster, reduce risk, and deliver consistent, guided experiences everywhere.

E2E Flow — Anonymous eCommerce (configure → order)

 

E2E Flow — Dealer Portal (configure → sales‑assist → quote/order)

Next Steps

Ready to unlock the power of headless configuration? Explore SAP CPQ’s API documentation or reach out to me SAP CPQ Solution Architect to learn how Configuration V2 can fit into your digital strategy.

API Documentation : Configurations v2 API

Create configuration: 

POST /api/configuration/v2/configurations
{
  "ProductSystemId": "LAPTOP-PRO-15",
  "Context": {
    "MarketCode": "US",
    "PricebookCode": "B2C",
    "CurrencyCode": "USD",
    "EffectiveDate": "2025-10-16",
    "InvolvedParties": [{ "Key": "SoldTo", "ExternalId": "CUST-123" }],
    "ExtensionFields": [{ "Name": "Channel", "Value": "WebshopA" }]
  }
}

 Get configuration: 

GET /api/configuration/v2/configurations/{configurationId}?$select=attributes,values,pricingDetails
Accept-Language: de-DE

 Patch configuration: 

PATCH /api/configuration/v2/configurations/{configurationId}
{
  "Attributes": [
    { "Id": 1001, "Values": [{ "Id": 9001, "IsSelected": true }] }
  ]
}

Delete configuration:

DELETE /api/configuration/v2/configurations/{configurationId}

Note: Not allowed if configuration is attached to a quote item.

entry.title: Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily outlines the process of transferring legacy data of OTC transactions (money market, foreign exchange, OTC derivatives, and trade finance) from external systems into the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module, as a critical step in initial go-live data migration. The process is illustrated using an example of interest rate instrument (a product category of money market) in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is recommended:

  • The position components constitute the financial position of an interest rate instrument – refer to blog Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument or relevant SAP held documents (e.g. Position Components) for detailed context.
  • How accrual of interest income or expenses works – refer to blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure or SAP help document Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues detailed context.

It is also recommended reading the blog Legacy Data Transfer - Security Position, which may help you gain insights into the differences between OTC transactions’ legacy data transfer and security positions’ legacy data transfer.

Migration of Transactions

The financial transactions can be imported into TRM by using the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit. For migration of interest rate instrument, the migration cockpit object “TRM - Interest rate instrument” can be used. You can find more information regarding data migration of TRM from help document Treasury and Risk Management.

The specific steps for importing transactions via the Migration Cockpit are not elaborated on here. We assume the following investment transaction of interest rate instrument has been imported into the system, which means, the transaction has been created in TRM.

Major contract elements:

  • Nominal amount: 1,000.000.00 USD
  • Payment amount: 998,000.00 USD (discount: 2,000.00 USD)
  • Term start: 01.10.2025
  • Term end: 01.04.2026
  • Interest rate: 3% (act/360)
  • Interest frequency: 2 months
  • Repayment structure: financial repayment

Cash flow:

Enter Position Component Values

Let’s assume that the go-live of TRM is planned at 01.01.2026, so that the position component values of this transaction as of 31.12.2025 should be also migrated from position management and financial accounting perspectives.

Previously in the migrated/created transaction, we specified a general valuation class which derives the valuation class and position management procedure for Fair Value through OCI (FVOCI) within the valuation area 002 (IFRS). In this illustrative example, we will always focus on valuation area 002 only, the details for legacy data transfer of other valuation areas are omitted although they are also needed.

The underlying message is that, in the legacy system, this transaction is also classified and measured at FVOCI, and the position of this transaction as of 31.12.2025 may include the position components of purchase value, security valuation (including Security Valuation, Not Affecting P/L), FX valuation, in the terminology of SAP TRM. In the meantime, the accrual of interest income based on the nominal interest up to 31.12.2025 should also be considered. Moreover, since the company code’s local currency is EUR, the valuation currency is EUR, which is different from position currency USD (=the transaction currency), the values in both USD and EUR should be considered during legacy data transfer.

You may ask why choosing FVOCI to illustrate legacy data transfer, it is because FVOCI is more complicated than other classifications, such as amortized cost (no security valuation) or FVTPL (no amortization).

Now, let’s enter the valuation area-dependent position component values for this transaction by using the app Enter Position Component Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63C). Screen-shots:

Elaborate the data entered in TPM63C in below table:

 

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

Position Value Date

31.12.2025

 

Company Code

1010

 

General Valuation Class

22

 

Valuation Area

002

 

Transaction

1000000000107

 

Position Currency

USD

 

Valuation Currency

EUR

 

Security Valuation in Position Currency

500.50

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, this is the security valuation (mark-to-market valuation) in PC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Security Valuation in Valuation Currency

426.23

In this example, this is the security valuation (mark-to-market valuation) in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

FX Valuation in Valuation Currency

-1799.10

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, this is the FX valuation in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Amortization in Position Currency

999.50

Positive value for positive amortization; Negative value for negative amortization.

In this example, this the amortization in PC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Amortization in Valuation Currency

851.17

In this example, this the amortization in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Security valuation, not affecting P/L, in position currency

500.50

Not needed if security valuation doesn’t update OCI (security valuation update P/L).

In this example, this the Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) in PC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 because of security valuation (which not affecting P/L) for the transaction in the legacy system.

Security valuation, not affecting P/L, in valuation currency

426.23

In this example, this the Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

2,583.33

Usually, positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from borrowing; negative value for accrual of expenses from borrowing, or deferral of income from investment.

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

2,195.31

Usually, positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from borrowing; negative value for accrual of expenses from borrowing, or deferral of income from investment.

Accrual/deferral with Reset

X

If this indicator is set, a reset business transaction for the transferred accruals/deferrals is generated additionally.

Reset Date

01.01.2026

If the reset date is not entered, the reset will occur on “position value date + 1”.

Notes:

  • Not every available field of TPM63C are listed in the above table.
  • Position component purchase value can’t be specified in TPM63C, because it has been determined by the operational cash flow within the transaction.
  • The amounts 2,583.33 USD / 2,195.31 EUR entered in the field “Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency” / “Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency” are the accrual account balances which represent the accrual for 31 days (01.12.2025 – 31.12.2025) out of the total 62-day calculation period (01.12.2025 – 01.02.2026) for the nominal interest flow due for payment on 01.02.2026.
  • In this example, the “Accrual/deferral with Reset” indicator is set, because the accrual of interest income for the nominal interest flows (update type MM1200+) after go-live will use Reset procedure. If the Difference Procedure for accrual will be used, then legacy data transfer for accrual part should be handled differently, there will be a separate section below to introduce it accordingly.

Beside manually entering the values via app TPM63C, there is a migration cockpit object “TRM - Position values” for mass importing the position component values.

Mark Flow as Fixed

After the transaction is changed to ‘contract settlement’ status, use app Mark Flows as Fixed - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TBB1_LC) to set the cash flows (up to 31.12.2025) to “Fixed” status without actually posting them.

The posting log is also available after successful execution of TBB1_LC, however, the document numbers are empty, because TBB1_LC doesn’t update general ledger accounting actually.

Check the cash flows in the transaction, the flows of principal increase (01.10.2025) and 1st nominal interest (01.12.2025) are “Fixed (not relevant for posting)”.

If you check the corresponding position flows through app Treasury Position Flows – Classic (app ID: TPM13), you will find they are also “fixed” in all valuation areas (screen-shot is omitted for TPM13 here).

It is highly recommended that you enter the exchange rates as of 01.10.2025 in the system (it is USD/EUR = 0.8516 in this this example), or edit the local currency amount of the cash flow with flow type 1100 in the transaction, before executing TBB1_LC. Because TBB1_LC will fix the valuation currency amount of MM1100- position flow, and update the position component of purchase value in valuation currency for position management. The MM1100- flow’s valuation currency amount (local currency amount in transaction’s cash flow) should reflect the corresponding exchange rate which was used to translate the transaction currency amount 998,000.00 USD to amount in EUR in the legacy system, otherwise the book value may not be correct in valuation currency amount after legacy data transfer.

You can also check the app Treasury Position Values - Classic (app ID: TPM12) for key date 31.12.2025. In TPM12, you can see the components Purchase Value in PC and Purchase Value in VC have been ‘determined’, and the deriving position component (e.g. acquisition value, amortized acquisition value, book value) are calculated accordingly.

Initial Load of Position Values

Use the app Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63) to read legacy data you’ve entered in TPM63C and transfer it to the position management of TRM.

There are 3 options for “Accounting Update”:

  • Do Not Update: choose this option if the accounting data is migrated via other means other than TRM (e.g. migrated the balances of position account, accrual account, OCI account in general ledger accounting). No posting will be generated from TPM63 if this option is selected.
  • Update: choose this option and then TPM63 will generate accounting documents for legacy data transfer related business transactions, usually using update type DT_*; and the postings rely on the account determination setup for those update types.
  • Update Only for Reset Business Transactions: if you have migrated accounting data by other means only up to the transfer key date, and you would like to post the reset business transactions (for amortizations, valuations, or accruals/deferrals) through TPM63, you can choose this option.

In this example, we choose Update to illustrate the whole picture of postings.

Log for TPM63 run:

You can also check the posting log by clicking Logs and Messages, the screen-shot is omitted here. Instead, let’s use the T-accounts to illustrate the effects of postings generated from TPM63 run:

First, look at the posting journals except the reset posting on 01.01.2026:

The position account, accrual account, and OCI account, all of the relevant balance sheet accounts have correctly reflected the balances which are equal to the legacy system’s data for this transaction, in both of position currency and valuation currency. The Financial Statement of Position as of reporting date 31.12.2025 then can be properly prepared in SAP system.

Please note the figures highlighted in orange are for the purchase value component. As previously mentioned, TPM63 doesn’t handle this position component, and TBB1_LC doesn’t make postings. To ensure the purchase value is presented in the position account balance as of 31.12.2025, there are at least two ways:

  • Post it directly in general ledger accounting; and the purchase value can be processed together with that of other transactions.
  • Use TBB1/TPM10 to post the business transaction of MM1100-, for which you may need to change its posting spec in advance. If this method is used, then TBB1_LC shouldn’t be used to fix MM1100-.

Check the position component values in TPM12 as of 31.12.2025:

Illustrate the calculation logic of position component values in the following manner:

Let’s then include the effects of DT_C013 posted on 01.01.2026:

At the date 01.01.2026, the balance of accrual account is zero, and interest income account is debited in posting period Jan. 2025 (entries are highlighted in green).

You may have a question: usually the migration for financial accounting data should be limited to balance sheet accounts, why reset business transaction DB_C013 posts to P&L account in this example? Let’s move to the next section “Month-End Close after Go-live”.

Month-End Close after Go-live

During the first month-end close for Jan. 2026 after go-live, run TPM1 valuation for this transaction, before that, the NPV (fair value, 998,900.00 USD) has been entered for 31.01.2026. Check valuation log (The specific logic is not elaborated on here):

Run TPM44 accrual for key date 31.01.2026. Check log:

It is worth noting that TPM44 picks up the MM1200+ nominal interest flow with calculation-from date 01.12.2025 and calculation-to date 01.02.2026, totally 62 days within its interest period, and the AD1000 business transaction covers 62 days as well and accrues the whole period of MM1200+. You may raise a concern that shouldn’t TPM44 only cover 31 days (01.01.2026 to 31.01.2026), as the cut-off date for migration is the end of 2025? Under reset procedure, TPM44 always calculates the accrual amount starting from the calculation-from date of MM1200+, disregarding that its calculation-from is prior to the cut-off date. That’s why DT_C013 should debit interest income at the beginning of 2025.

Let’s check the T-accounts and position components in the following manner.

With the joint effects of DT_C013 and AD1000 in period of January, the interest income recognized because of accrual (and reset of accrual) in Jan. 2026 = 5,166.67 - 2,583.33 = 2,583.34 USD, this is the amount of interest income in position currency arising from the nominal interest that is attributable to Jan. 2025 from accrual accounting perspective. This kind of posting logic ensures the correctness of Income Statement as of Jan. 2026.

If the difference procedure is used for accrual, the approach to legacy data transfer should differ—for details, refer to the next section.

Difference Procedure for Accrual

Besides modifying the configuration to the style of difference procedure in the configuration activity 102925 “Assign Update Types for Accrual/Deferral” which has been descried in blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure, additional configuration should be added in the configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, sample configuration as below:

The indicator “direction” indicates whether the update type functions as an accrual/deferral (+ Inflow) or as a reset (- Outflow) of accrual/deferral.

With this setting, TPM44 run after go-live will be able to consider the accrual recorded via legacy data transfer (e.g., DT_C011) and include it in the accrual calculation as an offset of MM1200+, under difference procedure.

Executing TPM63. The log of it:

Show the results in T-accounts as of 31.12.2025:

DT_C011 captures the amounts entered in the field “Accrual/deferral (1) in…currency” of TPM63C, while DT_C028 captures the amounts from the field “Accrual/deferral (2) in…currency” of TPM63C. From a posting standpoint, DT_C028 offsets against DT_C011, resulting in an accrual account balance of 2,583.33 USD / 2,195.31 EUR. This balance represents the accrual for 31 days (01.12.2025 – 31.12.2025) out of the total 62-day calculation period (01.12.2025 – 01.02.2026) for the nominal interest flow due for payment on 01.02.2026.

Run TPM44 for key date 31.01.2026 after go-live, the log is as below:

Because of the configuration made in 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, TPM44 incorporates DT_C011 into the accrual calculation, treating it as if the cumulative accrual that had been recognized via TPM44 in SAP TRM since the transaction’s inception and through 31.12.2025, and eventually results in the AD1004 business transaction representing the January’s incremental accrual amount 2,583.34 USD / 2,201.52 EUR, in addition, the FX correction business transaction 6.21 EUR with update type AD1020 is generated. The blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure explains this calculation logic of difference method.

Illustrating the positions of balance sheet accounts and situations of profit and loss (P/L) accounts as of 31.01.2025 (incorporating results generated from TPM1 and TPM44).

This blog has essentially come to a close. In the above examples, we assumed that the legacy system and SAP TRM adopt the same calculation and posting logic for position components, enabling direct one-to-one mapping during legacy data migration. However, this is not always the case in practice—there are usually some discrepancies between the two systems to varying degrees. How to address these discrepancies? Below are several alternative approaches for reference:

  • Treat the legacy OTC transactions as if they had been processed in SAP TRM from their inceptions, simulate the position component values as of the cut-off date in SAP TRM and use these simulated values as the “benchmark”. Any discrepancies between these values and those from the legacy system are adjusted in the financial statements as of the cut-off date, classified as accounting estimate changes or accounting error corrections, etc. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Accept the discrepancies between the legacy system and SAP TRM, and directly proceed with subsequent processing in accordance with SAP TRM logic. However, the results of subsequent measurement and derecognition after system go-live (e.g., amortization, foreign exchange valuation, realized gain/loss) may be inconsistent with those generated by the legacy system. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Modify the configuration in SAP TRM to align or approximate its processing logic with that of the legacy system. This approach is particularly applicable when the legacy OTC transactions were previously managed also in the TRM module of SAP ECC or S/4HANA On-Premise and now needs to be migrated to the TRM module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for continued management. entry.title: Legacy Data Transfer - Security Positions
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily outlines the process of transferring legacy data of security positions (bond, stock, investment certificate, etc.) from external systems into the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module, as a critical step in initial go-live data migration. The process is illustrated using an example of bond issuance in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is recommended:

  • The position components constitute the financial position of an interest rate instrument – refer to blog Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument or relevant SAP held documents (e.g. Position Components) for detailed context.
  • How accrual of interest income or expenses works – refer to blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure or SAP help document Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues detailed context.

The above-referenced blogs use OTC money market instrument for illustration, but the underlying principles are similar in essence.

It is also recommended reading the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which may help you gain insights into the differences between OTC transactions’ legacy data transfer and security positions’ legacy data transfer.

Migration of Transactions (?)

A frequently asked question is whether security transactions need to be imported into SAP TRM and how to handle them?

Actually, there is no need to import security transactions. Unlike OTC transactions— which serve as the core "carrier" (referred to as a differentiation term in SAP TRM terminology) for position management purpose and must be imported into the system—security positions are the result of the combined effect of multiple purchase/placement transactions, sale/redemption transactions, valuations, and other business transactions. Therefore, for data migration, it is sufficient to import the position of a specific security class in a given security account (disregarding discussion of other differentiation terms here) as of the cut-off date. Furthermore, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit does not provide a migration object for importing security transactions.

Creation of Master Data

Before importing the position data for security, two master data should be created: security class, security account.

Security Class

The specific steps for creating a security class are not elaborated on here. We assume the following security class has been created in SAP TRM.

Key elements of this security class:

  • Issue start: 01.10.2025
  • Issue end: 01.04.2026
  • Issuance currency: USD
  • Coupon rate: 3% (act/360)
  • Coupon frequency: every 2 months
  • Redemption structure: financial repayment

Simulate Cash flow (for position category “Liability”):

Security Account

The process of creating a security account (for issuance purpose) is omitted herein.

Enter Data of Position Indicator

Since the position indicator for security position can’t be generated through creation of security transaction (as aforementioned, security transaction creation is not required), you can use the app Enter Data of Security Position Indicators (app ID: TPM61A) to maintain the position indicator data for the security position.

In this example, we will always focus on valuation area 003 only, the details for legacy data transfer of other valuation areas are omitted although they are also needed.

Transfer Data of Security Position Indicators

With the app Transfer Data of Security Position Indicators (app ID: TPM61), you create the position indicator for the security class within the security account, and the subledger position indicator (for valuation area 003) is also created, based on the data maintained in TPM61A.

Log after successful execution of TPM61A:

Open app Manage Position Indicator (app ID: TPM57A) to check in the position indicator:

After the creation of position indicator, the security position value data should be then migrated, there are two parts for position value data of security:

  • Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions
  • Valuation Area-dependent Data of Security Positions

In this example, let’s assume that the go-live of TRM is planned at 01.01.2026, so the position values of this security class within the issuance security account as of 31.12.2025 should be migrated from position management and financial accounting perspectives.

Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions

With app Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions (app ID: TPM63A), you enter the valuation area-independent data of security positions for the position value date. You specify, for example, the nominal amount, purchase values, and capitalized costs in addition to the quantity information (units or nominal amounts).

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

-1.014.982,98

This is only needed when the amortization procedure of the position management procedure uses ‘gross method’ in SAP TRM; if amortization procedure uses ‘net method’, then there’s no need to enter value for these two fields of ‘Discount’ within TPM63B.

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

-258,333.33

Usually, enter positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from issuance; enter negative value for accrual of expenses from issuance, or deferral of income from investment.

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system, and the assumption is that SAP TRM use reset procedure for TPM44 accrual after go-live.

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

-219,531.66

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral with Reset

X

If this indicator is set, a reset business transaction for the transferred accruals/deferrals is generated additionally.

01.01.2026

If the reset date is not entered, the reset will occur on “position value date + 1”.

Notes: Not every available field of TPM63B are listed in the above table.

Initial Load of Position Values

After the data has been entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, use the app Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63) to read legacy data you’ve entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, and transfer it to the position management of TRM for this security position.

There are 3 options for “Accounting Update”:

  • Do Not Update: choose this option if the accounting data is migrated via other means other than TRM (e.g. migrated the balances of position account, discount account, accrual account in general ledger accounting). No posting will be generated from TPM63 if this option is selected.
  • Update: choose this option and then TPM63 will generate accounting documents for legacy data transfer related business transactions, usually using update type DT_*; and the postings rely on the account determination setup for those update types.
  • Update Only for Reset Business Transactions: if you have migrated accounting data by other means only up to the transfer key date, and you would like to post the reset business transactions (for amortizations, valuations, or accruals/deferrals) through TPM63, you can choose this option.

In this example, we choose Update to illustrate the whole picture of postings.

Log for TPM63 run:

You can also check the posting log by clicking Logs and Messages, the screen-shot is omitted here. Instead, let’s use the T-accounts to illustrate the effects of postings generated from TPM63 run:

The bond payable, unamortized discount, and accrual account, all of the relevant balance sheet accounts have correctly reflected the balances which are equal to the legacy system’s data for this security position, in both of position currency and valuation currency. The Financial Statement of Position as of reporting date 31.12.2025 then can be properly prepared in SAP system.

In this example, the “gross method” is used for the amortization procedure. Therefore, the bond payable account reflects the face value of the issued bonds (100,000,000.00 USD / 84,980,000.00 EUR, reflecting the latest exchange rate 0.8498). From an accounting standpoint, the carrying amount of the security position (short-term liability) is calculated as the face value minus the unamortized discount (1,014,982.98 USD / 863,397.80 EUR), resulting in 98,985,017.02 USD / 84,116,602.20 EUR.

You may wonder why accrual is reset on 01.01.2026—this is to ensure the accuracy of interest expenses for the month of January 2026 under the reset procedure of TPM44. For a detailed explanation of the rationale, please refer to the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which elaborates on the underlying reasons. While this blog uses an example of an investment OTC transaction, the core logic is consistent with the security position scenario, so we will not repeat the details here. This same blog also covers the handling of legacy data transfer for the difference procedure of TPM44, which requires assigning additional update types in configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, we will not elaborate further on this configuration step and process of difference procedure either.

Check the position flows in TPM13:

Check the position component values in TPM12 as of 31.12.2025:

Illustrate the calculation logic of position component values in the following manner:

This blog has essentially come to a close. In the above example, we assumed that the legacy system and SAP TRM adopt the same calculation and posting logic for position components, enabling direct one-to-one mapping during legacy data migration. However, this is not always the case in practice—there are usually some discrepancies between the two systems to varying degrees. How to address these discrepancies? Below are several alternative approaches for reference:

  • Treat the legacy security businesses as if they had been processed in SAP TRM from their inceptions, simulate the position component values as of the cut-off date in SAP TRM and use these simulated values as the “benchmark”. Any discrepancies between these values and those from the legacy system are adjusted in the financial statements as of the cut-off date, classified as accounting estimate changes or accounting error corrections, etc. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Accept the discrepancies between the legacy system and SAP TRM, and directly proceed with subsequent processing in accordance with SAP TRM logic. However, the results of subsequent measurement and derecognition after system go-live (e.g., amortization, foreign exchange valuation, realized gain/loss) may be inconsistent with those generated by the legacy system. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Modify the configuration in SAP TRM to align or approximate its processing logic with that of the legacy system. This approach is particularly applicable when the legacy security businesses were previously managed also in the TRM module of SAP ECC or S/4HANA On-Premise and now needs to be migrated to the TRM module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for continued management. In such cases, you can adjust the TRM configuration in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to make it consistent or closely aligned with the configuration in the former system.

  • In the example above, the issuance cost 12,000.000 USD is managed in a standalone composition component ‘capitalized costs’, which requires additional configuration modifications, the details are omitted herein.
